conclusion: Analyze the given information about the acceleration of the object over time.
The graph shows how the acceleration changes with time.
The object starts at rest and moves along a straight line.
The positive direction is the initial direction of motion.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the acceleration is constant and positive.
From t = 1 s to t = 2 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s^2 to 0.
From t = 2 s to t = 3 s, the acceleration remains zero.
From t = 3 s to t = 4 s, the acceleration becomes negative and constant.
Velocity can be found by integrating acceleration with respect to time.
Since the object starts from rest, the initial velocity is 0.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, v(t) = 2t, so at t = 1 s, v(1) = 2 m/s.
From t = 1 s to t = 2 s, v(t) = 2 + integral of (2 - 2(t-1)), resulting in v(2) = 3 m/s.
From t = 2 s to t = 3 s, v(t) = 3 m/s, velocity remains constant.
From t = 3 s to t = 4 s, v(t) = 3 - 2 = 1 m/s.
The maximum velocity occurs between t = 2 s and t = 3 s where velocity is constant at 3 m/s.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 s.
